subject: Re: [junit] Re: Coverting ANT test scripts to JUnit
msgSnippet: yes, perhaps... On Tue, 2002-12-31 at 07:36, Edwin Hautus  wrote: I am using Ant to setup and teardown the testing environment: the mkdir, copy, and delete
messageBody:
yes, perhaps...

On Tue, 2002-12-31 at 07:36, Edwin Hautus wrote: I am using Ant to
setup and teardown the testing environment: the
mkdir, copy, and delete tasks. Furthermore, I am calling javac from
Ant to test results of code refactorings performed by the application
under testing.

But as another poster mentioned, perhaps I should just leave these
tests in Ant.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Jason Rogers" <jacaetevha@f...> wrote:
> No offense but, how can we help without knowing what your scripts
do?
>
> =jason
>
> On Mon, 30 Dec 2002 16:33:44 -0000, "Edwin Hautus <ehautus@x...>"
> <ehautus@x...> said:
> > This message only has an HTML part -- this is a text generated
> > representation
> >
> >
> > I have just started to explore JUnit. So far I have used Ant
> > to write test-scipts (based on the command line interface for
my
> > application). Of course, these test are not really unit tests,
but
> > application tests. Nevertheless, they are very useful.
> > My question is therefore, does anybody have any ideas about
> > converting already existing Ant based tests to JUnit?
> > Basically, I am using some Ant functionality to copy
directories
> > files, call javac, and define some properties. I wouldn't like
to
> > rewrite all the scripts in Java, but calling Ant from JUnit
turns out
> > to be a bit ackward as well. Are there any other tools I might
want
> > to use?
> > Thanks for any help.
> > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:

Terms of
> > Service.

> >

> --
> Jason Rogers
> jacaetevha@f...
